questions.text: Which cognitive developmental stage is seen in a normal child of age 5 years
questions.solution:
• Piaget is recognized primarily as a genetic epistemologist, focusing on how children develop abstract thought based on biological and innate factors. His aim was to explain the progressive development of human knowledge.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Piaget identified four major stages of cognitive development. Each stage builds on the previous one, with individual progression influenced by innate abilities and environmental factors.

questions.text: Conservation of substance comes in which cognitive developmental stage?
questions.solution:
• Conservation is the ability to understand that objects maintain certain characteristics despite changes in shape. For instance, when a ball of clay is rolled into a long sausage shape, children recognize that both forms contain the same amount of clay. Inability to conserve, typical of the preoperational stage, is seen when a child thinks the sausage has more clay because it is longer.
  • Reversibility refers to the understanding that one thing can change into another and back again, such as ice transforming into water.

Option A: Sensorimotor stage:

  • Piaget's sensorimotor stage describes how infants learn through sensory observation and motor control, divided into six substages. Infants blend biology and experience to form learned behaviours, such as adapting their sucking reflex to locate a nipple. They develop schemas-basic concepts formed through interaction.
  • A critical achievement is object permanence, the understanding that objects exist independently of perception, allowing infants to search for dropped items. Around 18 months, they begin to develop symbolization, using mental images and words to represent objects. This transition marks the shift from the sensorimotor stage to the preoperational stage of development.

Option B: Preoperational thought stage:

  • During the Preoperational stage, children use symbols and language but think intuitively, lacking logical reasoning. They name objects but struggle with categories and cause and effect; for instance, they might believe a broken glass was meant to break. They perceive the same object in different contexts as separate items and define things by their functions, like calling a bike "to ride" and a hole "to dig."
  • In the preoperational stage, children struggle with moral dilemmas and often judge guilt based on quantity rather than intent, believing that more broken dishes mean more guilt. They hold a sense of immanent justice, thinking punishment for bad deeds is inevitable.
  • Egocentric in their thinking, children cannot understand others' perspectives and struggle to modify their behaviour for others. They also engage in magical thinking, believing events that occur together cause one another (e.g., thunder causes lightning) and exhibit animistic thinking, attributing life-like qualities to objects and events.

Option C: Concrete operations:

  • In the concrete operations stage, children interact with the tangible world and develop operational thought, allowing them to see others' perspectives. They begin using limited logical reasoning, can serialize and classify objects, and understand syllogistic reasoning (e.g., all horses are mammals; therefore, all horses are warm-blooded). This stage also fosters self-regulation and the development of a moral sense.

Option D: Formal Operations:

  • The formal operations stage involves highly logical, systematic, and abstract thinking. Adolescents can reason deductively, grasp probabilities, and explore complex issues like philosophy and ethics. They develop hypotheticodeductive thinking, allowing them to form and test hypotheses.
  • While they reflect on their own and others' thoughts, adolescents may show self-consciousness and occasionally revert to egocentric thinking. Not all adolescents enter this stage simultaneously or to the same degree; some may remain in the concrete operational stage throughout their lives.

questions.text: An 8 months old child admitted in a hospital shows separation anxiety due to which phenomenon
questions.solution:
• A key achievement during the sensorimotor stage is object permanence, which means that infants learn that objects still exist even when they can't see them. They begin to understand that they are separate from the world around them and can mentally hold an image of an object that is out of sight. For example, if they drop a toy, they will look for it, showing they recognize it exists independently.
  • Piaget's ideas have important implications for mental health. Children in the sensorimotor stage, like those in hospitals, often experience separation anxiety because they haven't yet developed object permanence. They feel more secure when their mothers stay with them overnight.

Option A: Immanent Justice:

  • Children in the preoperational stage struggle with moral dilemmas, even though they understand good and bad feelings.
  • For example, when asked who is more guilty- someone who breaks one dish on purpose or someone who breaks ten dishes by accident-young children often think the person who broke ten dishes is more guilty because more were broken.
  • They also believe in immanent justice, thinking that bad actions will always lead to punishment.

Option B: Reversibility:

  • Reversibility is the ability to understand that things can change and then change back.
  • For example, kids can see that ice can turn into water, and then water can freeze back into ice.
  • This understanding usually develops in children between the ages of 7 and 11 during the concrete operational stage.

Option C: Egocentric:

  • Children in the preoperational stage are egocentric, meaning they see everything from their own perspective and find it hard to understand others' views.
  • For example, if a child is told to be quiet because their sibling is studying, they might not listen because they can't see how their noise affects their sibling.
  • They focus only on their own feelings and needs.

Option D: Object Permanence:

  • Hospitalized children in the sensorimotor stage have not achieved object permanence and, therefore, have separation anxiety

questions.text: Which of the following was not a contribution of Sigmund Freud?
questions.solution:
• Sigmund Freud was the founder of Psychoanalysis. In his landmark publication Interpretation of dreams he presented theory of dreaming process being parallel to Psychoneurotic process.
  • He also gave topographical model of mind which divided mind into three regions: Concious, Preconcious, Unconcious
  • He gave psychosexual developmental stages:
  1. Anal stage
  2. Oral stage
  3. Urethral stage
  4. Phallic stage
  5. Latency stage
  6. Genital stage
  • He gave structural theory of the mind which had three provinces
  1. Id: reservoir of unorganised instinctual drives
  2. Ego: Rational mediator of reality
  3. Superego: Moral conscience and ideals
  • He also gave defence mechanism which are divided into 4 groups depending on degree of maturity
  1. Narcissistic- Psychotic
  2. Immature
  3. Neurotic
  4. Mature

Option A: Interpretation of Dreams

  • In The Interpretation of Dreams, Freud proposed that dreams reveal unconscious wishes and fantasies in disguised forms, facilitated by a mental "censor" that relaxes during sleep.
  • He noted that dreams are shaped by physical sensations, recent experiences, and repressed feelings, distinguishing between "manifest content" (what we remember) and "latent content" (deeper wishes).
  • The process of "dream work" transforms latent into manifest content, using neutral images to express intense feelings without causing distress.

Option B: Instinct/ drive theory

  • Freud focused on instinct theory, aiming to connect psychology to biology. This led to difficulties using biological terms for psychological constructs.
  • Modern research shows that instinctual patterns are influenced by learning, complicating Freud’s theory. He identified four characteristics of instincts: source, impetus, aim, and object.
  • Main instincts were: Libido, ego, aggression, life and death

Option C: Theory of attachment

  • He emphasized that proximity to a caregiver is essential for security, with maternal bonding influencing a child's attachment and development of independence. Without this secure base, a child's development suffers.

Option D: Theory of Narcissism

  • Freud used the term narcissism, derived from the Greek myth of Narcissus, to describe when an individual's libido is focused on the ego rather than others.
  • This concept complicated his instinct theory, leading him to connect it with various psychiatric disorders and even normal development, emphasizing inward libidinal withdrawal.

questions.text: During which Psychosexual developmental phase focus on castration in males and penis envy in females is seen.
questions.solution:
• Freud's psychosexual stages propose that personality develops through five stages: oral, anal, phallic, latency, and genital. Each stage centers on erogenous zones and influences later behaviour and relationships.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Phallic Stage

  • The phallic stage occurs from ages 3 to 5, focusing sexual interest on the genital area.
  • Children develop unconscious fantasies about the opposite-sex parent and experience castration anxiety and guilt over masturbation.
  • This stage lays the groundwork for gender identity and character organization, with pathologies linked to Oedipal conflicts and internalization of parental influences.

choices.text: To suppress the patient's defenses against painful memories
To help the patient establish and work through transference neurosis
To create a strong emotional bond between patient and analyst
To encourage the patient to focus solely on present issues

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of free association in psychoanalytic therapy?
questions.solution:
Option A: To suppress the patient's defenses against painful memories

While free association may lead to the uncovering of painful memories, its purpose is not to suppress defenses. Instead, it aims to bring forth thoughts and feelings that the patient may have been censoring. Suppressing defenses is counterproductive in psychoanalysis, which seeks to explore these defenses instead.

Option B: To help the patient establish and work through transference neurosis

Free association serves as a cornerstone of psychoanalytic technique by allowing patients to express their thoughts freely, which leads to the emergence of transference neurosis. This is a crucial aspect where patients project their childhood conflicts and emotional experiences onto the analyst, facilitating a deeper understanding and resolution of these issues.

Option C: To create a strong emotional bond between patient and analyst

While a therapeutic alliance is essential in therapy, the primary purpose of free association is not to foster this bond but to explore the patient's unconscious thoughts and feelings. The emotional bond can be a byproduct of the therapeutic process, particularly as transference develops, but it is not the main goal of free association.

Option D: To encourage the patient to focus solely on present issues

Free association does not encourage patients to focus solely on present issues. Instead, it allows them to explore their thoughts and feelings, which often leads to the revelation of past experiences and conflicts. This exploration is key to understanding how these past experiences affect present behavior and feelings.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Free association serves as a cornerstone of psychoanalytic technique by allowing patients to express their thoughts freely, which leads to the emergence of transference neurosis

choices.text: Development of a strong sense of justice

questions.text: What outcome may result from a failure to resolve the conflict between initiative and guilt in children?
questions.solution:
Erikson notes that unresolved conflict between initiative and guilt can lead to psychological issues such as conversion disorders or phobias. This is because the internalized guilt can stifle the child's initiative and lead to anxiety.

Option A: Development of a strong sense of justice: A healthy resolution leads to a sense of justice, but failure results in negative outcomes.

Option C: Enhanced curiosity and exploration: These traits would likely diminish due to the guilt and anxiety that result from unresolved conflicts.

Option D: Establishment of healthy relationships: Poor resolution of guilt typically leads to challenges in forming healthy relationships.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: unresolved conflict between initiative and guilt can lead to psychological issues such as conversion disorders or phobias

questions.text: What is the virtue associated with psychosocial stage Intimacy vs isolation?
questions.solution:
• Intimacy in young adults is linked to fidelity and commitment, requiring sacrifice. Fear of ego loss can lead to isolation and self-absorption.
  • Critics argue Erikson's focus on individual identity overlooks the importance of relational identity, especially for women.

questions.text: Which of the following concepts is NOT part of Jung's analytic psychology?
questions.solution:
Carl Gustav Jung, a Swiss psychiatrist, established analytic psychology, expanding on Freud’s theories. Key points include:

  • Collective Unconscious: A reservoir of shared human experiences and archetypes, representing universal symbols.
  • Archetypes: Fundamental images, such as the mother and hero, influencing personal experiences.
  • Personality Types: Distinguishing between introversion (focus on inner thoughts) and extroversion (orientation toward the external world).
  • Persona: The social mask individuals present to others, which may hide their true selves.
  • Individuation: A lifelong process of developing a unique identity and fulfilling creative potential, leading to new life paths.

Option A: Collective unconscious

The collective unconscious is a key concept in Jung's analytic psychology. It refers to the part of the unconscious mind that is shared among all people, containing universal symbols and archetypes.

Option B: Archetypes

Archetypes are fundamental components of Jung's theory. They are universal symbols and motifs found in myths, dreams, and art, representing shared human experiences.

Option C: Id, ego and superego

The id, ego, and superego are concepts developed by Sigmund Freud, not Jung. These elements describe the structure of the personality in Freud's psychoanalytic theory, focusing on drives, morality, and reality.

Option D: Persona

Incorrect. The persona is indeed a part of Jung's analytic psychology. It represents the social mask or façade that an individual presents to the outside world, influencing their interactions and self-perception.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The id, ego, and superego are concepts developed by Sigmund Freud, not Jung. These elements describe the structure of the personality in Freud's psychoanalytic theory, focusing on drives, morality, and reality

questions.text: Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) was introduced by
What phenomenon of learning is seen in this image?
questions.solution:
Option A: Classical conditioning

  • Classical conditioning is a learning process where a neutral stimulus becomes associated with a meaningful stimulus, eliciting a conditioned response.
  • Key points include:
  1. Unconditioned Stimulus(US): Naturally triggers a response (e.g., food causing salivation).
  2. Conditioned Stimulus(CS): Initially neutral but becomes associated with the US (e.g., a bell ringing when food is presented), leading to a learned response.

Incorrect options-

Option B: Operant Conditioning

  • Operant conditioning is a learning process where behaviours are modified through reinforcement or punishment.
  • Key points include:
  1. Reinforcement: Positive or negative consequences that increase the likelihood of a behaviour being repeated. For example, giving a dog a treat for sitting.
  2. Punishment: Consequences that decrease the likelihood of a behaviour. This can be positive (adding an unpleasant stimulus) or negative (removing a pleasant stimulus), like taking away privileges for misbehaviour.

Option C: Punishment

  • They are of two types:
  1. Aversive Punishment (Positive Punishment): Involves actively applying unpleasant stimuli (e.g., painful slaps, electric shocks, verbal reprimands) to weaken a behaviour. The response is diminished by the introduction of an aversive stimulus.
  2. Response Cost (Negative Punishment): Involves the removal of a pleasant stimulus to decrease a behaviour (e.g., taking away privileges). The response weakens due to the loss of a rewarding stimulus, emphasizing the consequences of the behaviour.

Option D: Negative reinforcement

  1. Positive reinforcement: It occurs when a response is strengthened by the subsequent presentation of a stimulus.
  2. Negative reinforcement: A response is strengthened by the subsequent removal (or avoidance) of an aversive stimulus

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Behaviour is governed by its consequences. Two major types of reinforcement strengthen responses and two major types of punishment weaken them. Operant behaviour also is weakened by extinction.

questions.text: Which memory briefly holds incoming sensory information in sensory registers?
questions.solution:
Memory refers to the processes that allow us to record, store and later retrieve experiences and information.


The three-stage model of memory. In this model, memory has three major components:

  • Sensory memory, which briefly holds incoming sensory information.
  • Working (short-term) memory, which processes certain information received from sensory memory and information retrieved from long-term memory
  • Long-term memory, which stores information for longer periods of time.

Option A: Short term memory:

Temporarily holds a limited amount of information for about 20-30 seconds, allowing for immediate processing and manipulation of data. Also known as working memory.

Option B: Recent memory

Refers to the ability to recall information learned or experienced in the past few days or weeks, still fresh in one's mind.

Option C: Immediate Memory:

Retains and recalls information for a very short duration, typically seconds, often tested through tasks requiring quick recall after presentation.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Sensory memory

It briefly holds incoming sensory information. It comprises different subsystems, called sensory registers, which are the initial information processors.

questions.text: Which memory is reflected through skills and actions?
questions.solution:
• Long term memory has two components: Declarative & Procedural
  • Episodic and semantic memories are declarative; their contents can be verbalized.
  • Procedural memory is nondeclarative; its contents cannot readily be verbalized.

Option A: Semantic memory

It represents general factual knowledge about the world and language, including memory for words and concepts.

Option B: Declarative memory

It involves factual knowledge

Option C: Non-declarative memory

It is reflected in skills and actions

Option D: Episodic memory

It is our store of knowledge concerning personal experiences: when, where, and what happened in the episodes of our lives.

questions.text: According to Maslow's hierarchy of needs which one is growth need?
questions.solution:
• Abraham Maslow proposed a motivational model in 1954 centred on personal growth.
  • He introduced a need hierarchy: deficiency needs (survival) at the bottom and growth needs at the top.
  • After basic needs, we focus on safety, progressing through the hierarchy.
  • Self-actualization is the ultimate motive, driving fulfilment of potential.
  • Most focus on lower needs, limiting growth, while a few (e.g., Einstein, Gandhi) contribute significantly and may achieve self-transcendence.

questions.text: Unconscious emotional response to sensory input occurs through?
questions.solution:
• Joseph LeDoux's research (2000) identified two neural pathways from the thalamus:
  1. High road: Sends sensory input to the cortex for detailed processing.
  2. Low road: Directly sends input to the amygdala for immediate emotional reactions.
  • The low road enables quick responses before the cortex interprets the situation.
  • This primitive mechanism has survival value, facilitating rapid reactions to potential threats.
  • Example: A hiker jumps at the sight of a snake, later realizing it was just a rope.

questions.text: Which is NOT a phase of Disaster Mental health?
questions.solution:
Different Phases of Disaster Mental Health

  1. Honeymoon Phase:
    • Relief agencies provide support (medical aid, food, shelter).
    • Survivors feel hope for community restoration; lasts 2-4 weeks.
  2. Heroic Phase:
    • Immediate altruistic behaviours from survivors (rescuing, sheltering).
    • Lasts from a day to weeks, influenced by severity and relief availability.
  3. Disillusionment Phase:
    • Resources dwindle; media and VIP attention fade.
    • Survivors face bureaucratic challenges and harsh realities.
    • Duration: 3-36 months; increased risk of mental health issues.
  4. Restoration Phase:
  • Gradual rebuilding and recovery; community regains stability.

choices.text: It is a fixed personality trait that cannot change
It serves as a biological building block for personality development
It is solely determined by environmental factors
It exclusively predicts adult behaviour without any influence from childhood experiences

questions.text: What is the primary function of temperament as described in the text?
questions.solution:
Temperament:

Definition:

  • Temperament refers to individual differences in emotional and behavioural styles, assumed to have a biological basis.

Early Indicators:

  • Traits such as emotionality, activity level, sociability, and impulsivity are evident in infancy.

Genetic Link:

  • Higher correlation of temperamental factors in identical twins suggests a genetic influence.

Inhibited vs. Uninhibited:

  • Inhibited children are shy and distressed in new situations; uninhibited children are outgoing and enjoy novelty.

Biological Basis:

  • The amygdala is involved in physiological responses related to inhibition.

Environmental Influence:

  • Environments can enhance or mitigate temperamental traits, impacting personality development.

Option A: It is a fixed personality trait that cannot change.

This is incorrect; Temperament has biological roots but it can be influenced by environmental factors over time.

Option B: It serves as a biological building block for personality development.

This is the correct answer. Temperamental factors influence the development of personality, acting as foundational elements.

Option C: It is solely determined by environmental factors.

This is misleading; the biological basis of temperament and its interaction with the environment, not a sole determination by environment.

Option D: It exclusively predicts adult behaviour without any influence from childhood experiences.

This is incorrect; temperament can influence adult behaviour, it is not a perfect predictor and is affected by childhood experiences.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Temperament refers to individual differences in emotional and behavioural styles, assumed to have a biological basis.

choices.text: It is a more intense form of depression
It lasts for a short duration with frequent episodes
It is a chronic and long-lasting form of depression

questions.text: What is the primary feature of dysthymia?
questions.solution:
Dysthymia

  • Dysthymia is a chronic form of depression characterized by a persistent low mood lasting atleast for two years.
  • Individuals feel ongoing sadness and hopelessness, but symptoms are less intense than major depression.
  • While they can function, there is often a sense of dissatisfaction with life.
  • Brief episodes of normal mood may occur, but they are typically short-lived, contributing to a lasting sense of misery.

Clinical Depression

  • Clinical depression, or major depressive disorder, involves severe symptoms that impair functioning significantly.
  • These symptoms are disproportionate to life circumstances and include profound sadness, loss of pleasure, difficulty concentrating, and low self-esteem.
  • Somatic issues like appetite and sleep changes are common. Professional intervention is often necessary for effective recovery.

Option A: It is a more intense form of depression.

This is incorrect; dysthymia is characterized by being less intense but more chronic compared to major depression.

Option B: It lasts for a short duration with frequent episodes.

This is incorrect; dysthymia is described as persistent, lasting for years with some brief periods of normal mood.

Option C: It is a chronic and long-lasting form of depression.

This is the correct answer. The text specifically defines dysthymia as a long-lasting condition with chronic symptoms.

Option D: It occurs exclusively in adults.

This is incorrect; dysthymia can occur in child and adolescents too.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Dysthymia is a chronic and long lasting form of depression.

choices.text: A lack of awareness or subjective experience
The ability to recall forgotten memories
The existence of an inner voice or thought

questions.text: What does Jaspers identify as a common element in all definitions of the unconscious?
questions.solution:
According to Jaspers, the unconscious is characterized by several key points:

  • Definition: It is not an experience, object, or self-aware knowledge.
  • States of Unconsciousness:
    • Brain Disease: A person may be unconscious due to severe brain conditions, reflecting a continuum from normal consciousness to death.
    • Sleep: Individuals in deep sleep are unconscious, illustrating another level on the continuum.
    • Selective Awareness: Even alert individuals are unaware of certain internal and external stimuli, indicating varying degrees of consciousness from full awareness to total unawareness.

Option A: The presence of subjective experience.
Jaspers explicitly states that the unconscious lacks subjective experience. The unconscious is defined by what is not experienced or recognized, contrasting with conscious awareness.

Option B: A lack of awareness or subjective experience.
Jaspers notes that a defining characteristic of the unconscious is the absence of subjective experience. In all forms of unconsciousness he describes, there is no awareness of internal or external stimuli.

Option C: The ability to recall forgotten memories.
The unconscious is not associated with recalling memories; rather, it is characterized by the absence of awareness of those memories. Memories may be repressed or unacknowledged, but this does not equate to being able to recall them.

Option D: The existence of an inner voice or thought.
The unconscious, as described by Jaspers, does not involve conscious thoughts or an inner voice. Instead, it represents a state devoid of the subjective awareness that characterizes conscious thought.

questions.text: Which stage in Conrad's model of delusional psychosis is characterized by a total change in perception of the world?
questions.solution:
Conrad proposed five stages in the development of delusional psychosis:

  1. Trema: delusional mood representing a total change in perception of the world
  2. Apophany: a search for, and the finding of, new meaning for psychological events
  3. Anastrophy: heightening of the psychosis
  4. Consolidation: forming of a new world or psychological set based on new meanings
  5. Residuum: eventual autistic state

Option A: Anastrophy

Anastrophy refers to the heightening of psychotic symptoms rather than the initial change in perception. This stage involves intensifying delusions rather than establishing them.

Option B: Trema

Trema is the stage that represents a total change in perception of the world. It signifies the beginning of delusional mood, where the individual's view of reality is fundamentally altered.

Option C: Consolidation

Consolidation is about forming a new psychological framework based on the new meanings discovered during the earlier stages, rather than the initial change in perception itself.

Option D: Residuum

Residuum refers to the eventual autistic state that follows the consolidation of delusional beliefs, representing withdrawal from reality rather than a change in perception.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Trema is the stage that represents a total change in perception of the world. It signifies the beginning of delusional mood, where the individual's view of reality is fundamentally altered.

choices.text: The ability to diagnose others with mental illnesses
The recognition that mental symptoms indicate a need for treatment
The capacity to manage symptoms without professional help
The awareness of how mental illness affects societal perceptions

questions.text: What does "insight" in psychiatry refer to regarding a patient's understanding of their mental illness?
questions.solution:
Insight in psychiatry is the patient's ability to recognize mental symptoms as indicators of illness requiring treatment, associated with impaired cognitive function and predicting poor treatment compliance.

Jasper's stages of insight:

  1. Understandable attitudes to the sudden onset of acute psychosis (perplexity, awareness of change)
  2. Working through the effects of acute psychoses
  3. Working through the illness in chronic states
  4. The patient's judgement of their illness
  5. The determination to fall ill
  6. The attitude to one's own illness: its meaning
  7. and possible implication

Option A: The ability to diagnose others with mental illnesses.

Incorrect. Insight in psychiatry focuses on a patient's self-awareness of their own mental health issues, not their ability to assess others.

Option B: The recognition that mental symptoms indicate a need for treatment.

Correct. Insight involves understanding that mental symptoms signify a mental illness requiring professional treatment, which is crucial for compliance and outcomes.

Option C: The capacity to manage symptoms without professional help.

Misleading. Insight generally includes recognizing the need for professional intervention, rather than believing one can manage symptoms independently.

Option D: The awareness of how mental illness affects societal perceptions.

Incorrect. Insight focuses on individual recognition of one's condition and its health implications, rather than societal perceptions.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Insight in psychiatry is the patient's ability to recognize mental symptoms as indicators of illness requiring treatment, associated with impaired cognitive function and predicting poor treatment compliance.

questions.text: Intense sense of rapture or blissfulness which is seen in Delirium & stuporous Mania is known as:
questions.solution:
• Dysphoric: An affect characterised by sustained emotional states such as sadness, anxiety or irritability.
  • Anxious: Feeling of apprehension caused by anticipation of danger which may be internal or external. Anxiety is an unpleasant affective state with the expectation, but not the certainty of something untoward happening.
  • Irritable: A state of poor control over aggressive impulses directed towards others; most frequently to those nearest and dearest. May manifest in outbursts in which a person is easily annoyed and provoked tom anger.
  • Depressed: Emotional mood tending towards sorrow. Relative passivity and diminished muscular tone with weeping.
  • Elevated: An exaggerated feeling of well-being out of keeping with the life situation.
  • Euphoric: Increased sense of well-being with cheerful thoughts and lack of response to depressing influence so that everything is seen in the best possible light.
  • Elated: Feeling of well-being and euphoria leading to faulty judgement, general over activity and disinhibited behaviour.
  • Exalted: Feeling of intense elation and grandeur; seen in Mania.
  • Ecstatic: Intense sense of rapture or blissfulness; seen in Delirium; stuporous Mania.
  • Euthymic: Mood in normal range implying absence of depressed or elated mood.

questions.text: Experience of seeing an image of one self in external space and knowing that it is oneself is called as-
questions.solution:
Option A: Phantom limb

  • It is a condition where individuals experience sensations, including pain or discomfort, in a limb that has been amputated or is missing.
  • This phenomenon occurs due to changes in the brain and nervous system following the loss.

Option B: Autoscopy

  • It is the experience of seeing an image of oneself in external space, often called the phantom mirror image.
  • It includes various types, such as autoscopic hallucination, heautoscopy, feelings of presence, out-of-body experiences, and negative autoscopy, often involving visual perception anomalies and sensations of detachment.

Option C: Pseudohallucinations


Option D: Illusion

  • It is a perceptual experience where an individual perceives something that differs from reality.
  • This can involve visual, auditory, or sensory distortions, leading to misinterpretations of stimuli. Illusions highlight the complexities of perception, revealing how the brain organizes and interprets sensory information, often influenced by context and expectations.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: It is the experience of seeing an image of oneself in external space, often called the phantom mirror image.
